text: I'm an undergrad at um Ruckers
University in New Jersey. And so
currently I'm a junior and I have about
a year left in my undergrad. So I took
what my friends like to call a
sbatical to Harvard to try to do some
work. Um, but I hope to return and um
and to be able to finish my undergrad
degree. And
um I once wanted to go to med school,
but then one of my mentors sat me down
and said very prophetically, Kyle,
you're never going to medical school.
You're going to graduate school. So I
guess I'm going to grad school
now. I'll have to say I'm very surprised
when I say this, that a lot of it came
from myself. So that I know when I was
very young, my parents would bring home
books just to read for themselves or
something and that I would just pick up
these biology books just cuz I was bored
or something and that I just really got
excited into it. And I think that it's
really impossible to do something if
someone is telling you you have to do
it. So, I think that it's really been
important for me that I'm always really
excited about science and that um I
pursue a lot of it by myself and I keep
on trying to read and talk to new people
and try to get new ideas. And I think
that's what what the fun
is. The more I think about it, I think
if you stay in one thing too much, it's
really unhealthy. Like staying in
science can too much, can be really
unhealthy.
um staying being with girlfriends and in
a relationship for a long time can be
also
unhealthy. Um so in Ruckers I try to
take a balanced course load so I can
advance my science goals but also
liberal arts as
well. I think that it's really
impossible to do something unless you
really care about something and I think
that's the way for science and for
academics and for
friends. And I think most importantly
there just needs to be some kind of
functional connection that once you hit
something you know it just kind of
clicks and that you need to aggressively
pursue that a lot. So I was very
fortuitous that my first experience with
science was stem cells and that was just
a very natural fit and I think that the
first real really really big step is
just finding something you believe in
and then after that you can definitely
make things happen and that I know there
have been a lot of roadblocks personally
in my way but that I think if you really
believe in something you and your family
and your friends can really make it go
through and it's a matter of finding
good mentors and that's normally
professors at universities and those can
help you just
infinitely. I think it can be an
academically stifling environment for
someone that has a lot of ideas and it's
just kind of in this constrained system.
And so I guess my advice is
that I think it really requires a big
leap of faith to try something like
going to college early and that but the
really the more I think about it I think
that a standardized system might
actually be a lot better for a lot of
people and thinking about myself I even
wonder I think I might be a lot better
person if I had gone through the normal
way. And I think that while that it's
very easy to think that class is very
boring and that it's difficult to fit
in, I think that the social environment
is just infinitely important. And that I
think that if you can have fun and have
friends, that matters a lot more than
having a good CV or taking classes that
are challenging.
